bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mrs. George Carroll, May 10, 1956

div1.p: Hench describes his continuous attempts to contact her husband, George Carroll, and his lack of success.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mrs. George Carroll, May 10, 1956
div1.opener:
Written from Hotel Sheraton - Schcdere
Baltimore
May 10, 1956
My dear Mrs. Carroll
div1.p:
Telegrams are so short and when read they can seem so cold and impersonal.
Therefore, I want to write you this note (through the help of a typist here in
Baltimore) to supplement the night letter I sent you last night. I was still
in California after the meeting of the American College of Physicians when
your letter of May 2nd reached Rochester, and I did not get to my office to
read it until just before I had to leave to come here, where I am giving two
lectures (yesterday and today) at the Johns Hopkins Hospital.

I wanted to write, instead of wiring you yesterday but I had no one to type
for me. Nevertheless, I did want you to have an answer from me as soon as pos-
sible--hence, my telegram. I think I can, in a letter, add some words that will
make my wire clearer.

Mrs. Carroll, in your recent letter you wrote me very frankly. You said you
didn't want to be rude but you were disturbed about something and you were simply
taking the opportunity to write me frankly. Now that is what I want between you
and me, frankness and friendliness and when I read your letter just before leav-
ing (I took it home to bring along with me) I was not disturbed. I knew there
was a misunderstanding. I thought you must have written it without reading care-
fully my earlier letters to you--those of February 26th and April 26th, 1954.
After all you would hardly have those two-year-old letters handy. I remembered
very clearly that all I had asked of you during our long chat of February 19, 1954
was permission to borrow the photographs and that I would have them copied (re-
photographed) carefully and would then return to you not only the originals but
extra copies for you to send to your husband's sisters if you wished to. I knew
what I personally had done since then to bring these back to you personally, and
knew that I had tried honorably to fulfill my promise.

Knowing this, when I read your letter the first time I said to myself: “That's
too bad; she doesn't recall how I've missed finding her at least twice. But I'm
on my way there now. I will find her at home and then give her the photos, and
show her again how well I appreciate her friendliness and cooperation; we will have
a cheerful laugh together over the misunderstanding and all will be well.”

Then on the plane coming here, I read your letter again, this time more lei-
surely and carefully. I noted what I had not fully appreciated before--the sen-
tence in your second paragraph where you write: “In looking over my correspon-
dence with you - - - ”. The first time I read it I assumed you meant that you
had looked over my correspondence with you. But reading it several times now I
realize that you probably meant just what you said and that you meant you had re-
read your correspondence to me. This could mean, or seems to me to mean only one
thing,--that you have written to me since my visit of February, 1954, and that
I had never gotten it; furthermore that you, not hearing from me in reply, thought
I was ignoring you and trying to postpone the return of your photographs.

Since re-reading your letter and gathering this idea from it, I have been quite
upset because, my dear Mrs. Carroll, I can assure you I would never do that!
Furthermore, I hasten to tell you that there has been absolutely no correspondence
from you to me that I ever got! If you wrote me once--or more, perhaps, since my
visit, I never got the letter or letters. Indeed I have been somewhat upset
-2-
because I never did hear from you in answer to my letters of February 26, 1954
or April 26, 1954. And now it would appear that you must not have received my
letters either!! What an unfortunate situation!

In my letter of February 26, 1954, I reported to you the progress I was
making with respect to the copying of your photos, I told you of the special
care--the extra special care--I and the Chief of the Mayo Clinic Photographic
Department were taking to see that nothing would happen to harm them. I told
you I would not only return them to you but would send you copies of the origi-
nals so that you could have them in case anything ever happened to the originals.

In that letter I offered to send extra copies of these photos to you in case
you wished to send them to Dr. Carroll; sisters. Furthermore, I said I was
making (as soon as possible) a copy of the rough list I had made of the material
in the trunk--a copy for you, and that if you wanted them I would send you extra
copies for you to give to your husband's sisters and one for your lawyer, but
only if you wished. I said I would not correspond with your sisters-in-law or
with your lawyer. I did this because you had honored me with your trust and
friendship and confidence and had told me frankly that you preferred that they
would not learn of my visit with you; that they might misunderstand and start
troublesome inquiry which would be quite unnecessary because you were merely
lending me these photos.

In that letter I also told you I was sending you by separate post a copy of
Dr. Kelly's book. I had found out that you had no copy and would like one. I
had an extra one, wanted you to have it (who would have a better right to such
a copy), and sent it. (I do hope it arrived. Perhaps it did not, for I have
never heard. That would be too bad indeed for copies of that book are rare.
That extra copy I was actually saving for my medical-school son, but when I heard
you didn't have one I just decided to give my extra one to you at once and hope
that sometime I could find another for him). Please do tell me if you never re-
ceived it!

In that same letter I suggested ways in which the yellow fever data could be
copied in the most convenient way possible for you.

When I did not hear from you I assumed you might be away as you had told me
you were so very lonesome in your home. So I waited two months and wrote again
on April 26, 1954 for two reasons: to tell you to be sure to accept the invita-
tion to the Cuban embassy affair and to report again about the photos. I told
you I had sent copies of your photos to some “survivors” or interested people
(Lambert, Tate, etc.) to see if they could identify the people in the one photo,
as you did not know them nor did I. Not having heard from you I didn't know
whether to trust your photos to the mail so I decided to abide by your decision.
If you wanted me to mail them I would; if you hated to trust them to the mail even
though registered, (and I hated to mail them,) I would bring them myself to you on
my next visit.

Again I had no answer and I can now only believe that you were away and never
got that one letter. I could only do one thing, put the photos away for safe
keeping until I could contact you or hear from you. I have a large safe deposit
box in the bank and also a safe just to see that such sentimentally and histor-
ically important material is not lost.

And so I did that until I could try to find you personally. I came to
Washington at least twice, actually I think it has been three times that I have
carried your photos back and forth. On each visit I either phoned your Rhode
Island Avenue house or, if I had no answer, drove out in a taxi, but never once
could I locate you. Once I phoned your old address downtown where I had first
called in 1941, but of course you were not there. As I recall, once I called
your lawyer, but I hesitated to do this because you told me you didn't want him
to “Bother about your business” too much, and so I only asked where you might
be located but the office did not know.

Now, my dear friend, what more could I possibly have done? I could only
think of two things--either you had lost interest in them and had no concern in
telling me how and when and where to return them, or that you were sick or away
and that in due time I would hear. If the first supposition were true (and I
couldn't believe it) I determined even so to look you up and return them. If
the second were true I would certainly not send the photos by mail, have perhaps
some tenant or relative receive them in your home and possibly misplace or lose
them before you returned.

And so now that you know how carefully I have tried to carry out what I
thought were your wishes, now that you know that I have kept full faith with
you, I hope you will forgive me for what you must have wondered about if you
never did hear from me. And knowing how that I have never heard from you after
either letter or the book I'm More you will forgive and understand why you never
heard from me in specific reply.

But let me comment on just one thing more. From reading your letter I sense
a continuation of the grief and lonesomeness which you were still suffering when
I visited you. This does distress me for I had so much hoped that with time
your most understandable sorrow would lessen. I had heard indirectly (was it
from your doctor? I can't recall) that you had decided against an operation.
Now I'm so sorry to hear that you had it and were disappointed.

I wish indeed I could help somehow. Is there any way you think I could
help you through your physician? You told me once that you had thought of coming
to the Mayo Clinic and I told you I would do everything I could to see that, if
you did come, you would get the very best advice our whole institution could
provide. Indeed I made inquiries at the clinic about the possible cost of this
and that, but you did tell me you hated to go away so far and that your own family
physician wasn't sure you needed an operation at that time.

But if now, or soon you think you would like a thorough medical check-up, I
will be more than glad to help you and your physicians in Washington arrange it
so that what useful data they have need not be repeated in Rochester.

Just one last word. Everyone of us in medical or spiritual trouble needs
friends. In view of the sympathetic and skillful services of your own physicians
you do not need my help in that way. But I rather thought--indeed I flattered
myself--that my friendship meant something to you and that I was somehow helping
you just a little wee bit during our long day's visit, because you and I could--
and did--talk for hours about things and people that interested us both--and we
-4-
talked very little about yellow fever.

I hope and believe that our friendship may continue and I hope you have
accepted my friendship without particular regard to my very sincere interest in
your father-in-law's memorable contributions. You know how determined I am to
honor him and his memory, and indeed it is not too late, for that story will
never die and the truth of the story just makes it all the more thrilling. But
as I have had the wonderful pleasure of making real friends with so many of the
fine men who were in Cuba in 1900--Moran, Kissinger, Lambert, the Lazears and
others, so I have valued our relationship, yours and mine, something that de-
pended on much more than whether or not I had copies of this or that, something
that, as far as I am concerned, will continue long after you might have let
everything be copied! Friends mean a lot more than that to me, and I have be-
lieved--and hope-- that my friendship means more than that to you. If I haven't
made that clear, then somehow I have failed in showing you my sincerity.

In your lovely letter of November 4, 1953, you ended by sending “Kindest
regards to you and your most gracious wife whom I met several years ago.” Your
words pleased me very much because my dear wife is very gracious and very lovely.
She was very sorry that you did not feel able to join us a few years ago when we
had a little dinner party at our hotel. But we hope that on another visit she
will come with me and that we can have another chance for a pleasant, quiet
evening. Our younger daughter (she's very lovely too!) who was married Christ-
mas, 1954 and now lives in Bethesda is going to have her first baby in late June.
Mrs. Hench hopes to be with her for three weeks to help out. Unfortunately I
cannot be with them then as two years ago I promised an old friend I would speak
at a medical congress in France which he was arranging. So I must keep my
promise (I always try to!) and go to France for a quick trip in June.

closer.seg:
P.S. After all this, I almost forgot to say that I will do my best to get in
touch with you Friday if at all possible or certainly Saturday and we will both
feel easier when your wonderful old photos are back safe in your keeping. If my
daughter, Susie weren't eight months pregnant I'd like to bring her along, but
she's not up to it this time.
